ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Polarization-based immunoassay in aqueous solution using Au nanoparticle-labeled antibody

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Graduate School of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Here we describe an ultrasensitive antigen-antibody immunoassay using gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). Polarization microscopy is used to discriminate individual AuNP dimers from isolated single AuNPs by means of their Brownian motion in aqueous solution. The optical anisotropy and rotational diffusion time were measured to provide accurate and robust discrimination. Since the size of a naked antibody is comparable to that of an AuNP, the distance between two AuNPs (inter-dimer distance) is rather large, and therefore the optical anisotropy is seriously degraded. To address this problem, we digested the antibody with the protease pepsin to reduce the distance. Autocorrelation analysis allowed discrimination of the difference in optical anisotropy and rotational diffusion time. Setting an appropriate threshold for the measurement enabled sufficient accuracy in the discrimination.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Optical biosensing using nanoparticles as labels to detect specific analytes has been intensively studied for potential applications in biomedical diagnostics and environmental monitoring, among other areas. In particular, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) are versatile and widely used due to their attractive properties, including brightness (large scattering cross section) enhanced by localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR), good stability, and high biocompatibility [1–3]. The spectroscopic tunability of LSPR also contributes to broadening the application of AuNPs. To date, immunoassays using AuNPs have been used in practical applications such as flu diagnosis and pregnancy tests.

Compared to heterogeneous assays, homogeneous assays are faster, less labor-intensive, and more amenable to automation because the only operation is the addition of the target molecule to the probe solution [4]. One promising homogeneous assay application that takes advantage of AuNPs is a colorimetric immunoassay, in which the aggregation of AuNPs induced by the immunoreaction of antigen and AuNP-labeled antibody is easily characterized by a visible color change of the solution [5–8]. Although this method provides a simple, rapid, and low-cost diagnostic tool, it requires a large quantity of antigen, and therefore it is difficult to detect target molecules at extremely low concentrations, such as in the early detection of cancer [9, 10]. We previously proposed a method for counting a small number of AuNP dimers among a large number of individual AuNPs in Brownian motion in solution, and demonstrated the feasibility of this approach by applying it to DNA hybridization assays. Single-particle polarization microscopy was performed to discriminate dimers from monomers. For sensitive and robust discrimination of individual particles, the optical anisotropy and rotational diffusion time are measured: the dimer exhibits much larger anisotropy compared to the nearly spherical monomer, and the rotational diffusion time of the dimer is four times larger than that of the monomer [11–14].

In this paper, we employed the above method in an antigen-antibody immunoassay to demonstrate the feasibility of this approach. The rather large size of the antibody molecule comparable to that of an AuNP means that the distance between two AuNPs is large, thus greatly reducing the optical anisotropy [15]. To address this problem, we digested the antibody with the protease pepsin to reduce the inter-dimer distance [16, 17].

Section2.Heading: Sample preparation
Section2.Para:
The typical size of an antigen-antibody complex is comparable to that of AuNPs used in immunoassays (Fig. 1(a)). This makes the distance between two AuNPs larger compared to the intermolecular distances in DNA hybridization assays and drastically reduces the optical anisotropy of the AuNP dimer. To solve this problem, we cleaved the antibody to almost half its length using a protease, pepsin (Fig. 1(b)).
Fig. 1
Sandwich immunoassay with AuNPs for antigen detection. AuNPs are functionalized with (a) naked (undigested) and (b) digested antibodies

The procedure for the synthesis of the AuNP dimer formed by the antigen-antibody coupling reaction is as follows. We used AuNPs with a diameter of 80 nm at an initial concentration of 170 pM (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo, Japan). After ultrasonically dispersing the AuNP colloidal suspension for 15 min, 1 ml of the suspension was mixed with 100 μl of antibody solution (diluted with 1×TE buffer), then incubated at 50 °C for 1 h. In this experiment, we used two types of digested anti-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) antibody: anti-hCG 5008 SP-5, and the anti-alpha subunit, 6601 SPR-5 (Medix Biochemica, Finland). These antibodies react with different parts of the antigen, making the formation of the AuNP-antibody-antigen-antibody-AuNP complex possible. Both antibodies were cleaved with pepsin to yield a F(ab′)2 fragment and Fc fragments using a Pierce® F(ab′)2 Micro Preparation Kit (Thermo Scientific, Japan). We prepared two batches of AuNPs functionalized with these two antibodies. The AuNPs from both batches were further functionalized with 110 μl of 10 % BSA (bovine serum albumin) solution (100 mg/ml in 1×TE) and incubated at 50 °C for 1 h. After washing three times by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 15 min with 1 % BSA buffer, the AuNPs were incubated overnight at 4 °C to allow them to chemically stabilize. Both batches were then mixed and hCG antigen (9 nM, diluted with 1 % BSA buffer) was added. The mixture was then incubated at room temperature for 1 h to form dimer AuNPs by immunoreaction of the antigen and antibody (Sample A).

From transmission electron microscope (TEM) observation of Sample A, we estimated that 5 % of the AuNP population consisted of dimers and 1 % consisted of trimers, with the remaining 94 % remaining as monomers. We also checked AuNPs after mixing the two batches but without adding the antigen (Sample B) and found that 1 % of the AuNPs were present as dimers due to unintended reaction with antibodies unrelated to the target antigen-antibody coupling reaction. Furthermore, as a control for non-specific binding, we performed the test against another human antigen, prostate-specific antigen (PSA, Sample C).

Figure 2 compares the electrophoretic separation of AuNPs modified with digested and undigested antibodies. Successful AuNP dimer formation was observed in both cases. The difference in the flow distance arises from the fact that AuNPs functionalized with digested antibody exhibit higher electrophoretic mobility.
Fig. 2
Electrophoretic separation of single AuNPs and AuNP dimers formed by antigen-antibody reaction. (a) AuNPs functionalized with IgG-antibody (undigested). (b) AuNPs functionalized with digested antibody, IgG-F(ab′)2. In both figures the left lanes show samples in the absence of added antigen (i.e., just a mixture of the two batches) for reference

Section2.Heading: Optical measurement setup
Section2.Para:
A measurement setup for single particle microscopy is illustrated in Fig. 3. Individual AuNP monomers and dimers in sample solution were illuminated with a linearly polarized laser diode (λ=670 nm) through an objective with a numerical aperture of 0.85. Light scattered from AuNPs traversing the observation volume by Brownian motion was collected by the same objective. A pinhole was used to reject out-of-focus light, thus increasing the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). To measure the polarization state of the scattered signal, the signal was split into two orthogonally polarized components, and their intensities, I
x and I
y , were detected by two photodiodes. The difference in the intensities, I
x –I
y , is a measure of the optical anisotropy of the AuNP monomers and dimers.
Fig. 3
Optical measurement setup for polarization microscopy of single AuNP monomers and dimers in Brownian motion in aqueous solution

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 4(a) is a representative time trace of I
x , I
y , and their difference (I
d ≡I
x −I
y ) for an AuNP monomer in Sample B. Figure 4(b) shows the same parameters for an AuNP dimer in Sample A. High frequency noise is dominant in the monomer, and no noticeable difference signal is observed due to the isotropic nature of the spherical particle. On the other hand, for the dimer, a significant difference signal was observed due to the large optical anisotropy of the complex. Fluctuations in the difference signal correspond to rotational diffusion under Brownian motion.
Fig. 4
Representative time traces of I
x , I
y , and I
x –I
y for (a) an AuNP monomer and (b) a dimer

To obtain a quantitative measure of the discrimination between monomers and dimers, we calculated the autocorrelation function
1
$$ G(\tau) = \int_{0}^{T} I_{d}(t)I_{d}(t + \tau)\,dt, $$ where T is the overall measurement time. The autocorrelation function provides a measure for the self-similarity of a time sequence signal and thus the persistence of information carried by the signal. In this measurement the characteristic decay constant of G(τ) is proportional to the rotational diffusion time, as will be described below. Autocorrelation curves (a) and (b) of Fig. 5 were obtained from the time traces in Figs. 4(a) and 4(b), respectively. When the noise frequency is higher than 1/ΔT and where ΔT=5 μs is the detection time interval in the measurement, the unwanted high frequency noise component is eliminated in the value of G(ΔT). Unlike common autocorrelation analysis, non-normalized G(τ) is useful for discriminating between monomer and dimer, because G(τ) can take account of the fact that the dimer exhibits a larger scattering cross section and slower translational diffusion (longer signal duration time), as well as a larger optical anisotropy, than the monomer. Furthermore, to make the discrimination more concrete, we also employed the decay time constant, which reflects the difference in the rotational diffusion time between monomers (T mono) and dimers (T di). Since G mono(τ)/G di(τ) decays as exp[−(1/T mono−1/T di)τ] and it is known that T di≈4×T mono, at an appropriate time delay τ=T rot, G(T rot) will provide a more robust measure for the discrimination. In this study we adopted T rot=150 μs to avoid artifacts caused by the oscillation of G(τ) due to the limited measurement time (10 ms).
Fig. 5
Autocorrelation curves of (a) an AuNP monomer and (b) a dimer calculated from the I
x –I
y signals in Fig. 4

Figure 6 shows histograms of Γ≡G (150 μs) for 1,000 particles obtained from Sample A (the antigen-antibody reaction), Sample B (no antigen added), and Sample C (PSA added), respectively. The measurement time for 1,000 particles was 10 min. For smaller Γ, the distributions from the three samples overlap because 81 % of the AuNPs in Sample A are still monomers. For larger Γ, the number of AuNPs in Sample A far exceeds that in Samples B and C. This result reflects the difference in the quantity of dimers in Samples A–C and demonstrates that we can successfully discriminate dimers from monomers. At sufficiently large Γ, Γ>1 for example, the number ratio of AuNPs between Samples A and B (also A and C) should be 5:1 from TEM measurements. Therefore, the experimental result of 4:1 is smaller than expected and is probably due to larger and/or distorted AuNPs, as well as unintended dimers in Samples B and C, also giving rise to Γ values larger than 1. Although smaller AuNPs show better uniformity in size and shape, the distance between two particles relative to the diameter of either particle becomes larger and the optical anisotropy is reduced. Optimization of AuNP size should therefore be addressed for more accurate discrimination.
Fig. 6
Histograms of discrimination index Γ obtained from Sample A (with hCG addition), Sample B (without addition of antigen), and Sample C (with PSA addition). The value of frequency at Γ=10 includes the particles having Γ>10

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Our aim is to design ultrasensitive AuNP sandwich immunoassays. We employed single particle polarization microscopy to discriminate between AuNP monomers and dimers in Brownian motion in an aqueous solution. For accurate and robust discrimination, the difference in optical anisotropy and rotational diffusion time was carefully examined by autocorrelation analysis. Digesting the antibody to reduce the distance between the two AuNPs forming a dimer allowed accurate discrimination of monomers from dimers using optical anisotropy. Unintended dimerization and larger and/or distorted AuNPs determine the limit in target detection sensitivity. Optimization of AuNP size will be needed in order to further improve accuracy and sensitivity.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: We are grateful to Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo for providing high-quality gold nanoparticles. This research was supported by a Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (S) from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology of Japan.
